name: ZAYTUNA COLLEGE
mission: Zaytuna College aims to educate and prepare morally committed professional, intellectual, and spiritual leaders, who are grounded in the Islamic scholar...
programs: BA in Liberal and Islamic Studies
Center for Ethical Living and Learning (ZCELL)
theoryOfChange: By training the mind through the trivium and quadrivium alongside Islamic primary texts, the college produces leaders who can navigate modern society with moral and spiritual grounding.

evaluationSources: Accredited by WASC Senior College and University Commission (WSCUC)

zakatClaimEvidence: According to many scholars, institutions such as Zaytuna College meet the requirements for zakat eligibility. However, we have chosen to limit the zakat funds only to the total cost of education for zakat eligible students and not for any other institutional expenditures. We take this sacred trust very seriously, so if you choose to give a portion of your zakat to Zaytuna College, we will do our utmost, God willing, to ensure its most judicious and shariah compliant use. (Source: https://zaytuna.edu/ways-to-give)

ui_signals_v1.recommendation_rationale: Context dependent profile. Consider cause fit, risk profile, and evidence maturity before deciding.

score_details.score_summary: ZAYTUNA COLLEGE shows good alignment and moderate impact, with zakat compliance (minor risk deductions applied).

all_citations.claim: The charity reports a total revenue of $18,359,667, a program expense ratio of 56.0%, and fundraising efficiency of $0.11 per $1 raised.
Financial data confirms the organization's revenue and asset management for the 2023 fiscal year.
Zaytuna College offers a Bachelor of Arts in Liberal Arts and Islamic Studies and is a recognized accredited institution.
The college provides a Master of Arts in Islamic Texts and maintains specific accreditation status.
The curriculum is designed to integrate the Islamic and Western scholarly traditions.
Zaytuna College is zakat-eligible and provides various methods for charitable giving.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: Zaytuna College earns a moderate overall score due to its strong financial reserves and specialized educational niche, balanced against a program expense ratio that suggests significant resources are directed toward administrative or development costs.
areas_for_improvement: program expense ratio of 56.0% is lower than the industry benchmark for high-performing educational nonprofits
Limited public data regarding specific long-term career outcomes for all graduates

dimension_explanations.alignment: The institution shows medium donor fit for those seeking to support Islamic higher education, addressing a specific need for accredited Muslim institutions in the West [3][7]. Its status as a zakat-eligible organization provides a structured pathway for Muslim donors to fulfill religious obligations through educational philanthropy [8].
dimension_explanations.impact: The college focuses on capacity building by educating future intellectual leaders, reporting a total revenue of $18,359,667 to support its academic infrastructure [1][2]. While it maintains a robust 33.6 months of working capital, its program expense ratio is 56.0%, indicating that just over half of its total spending is directly applied to its primary educational programs [1].

baseline_narrative.headline: Zaytuna College serves as the first accredited Muslim liberal arts college in the United States, dedicated to grounding students in both Islamic and Western scholarly traditions.
strengths: High financial stability with 33.6 months of working capital
Exceptional fundraising efficiency at $0.11 per $1 raised
Maintains formal accreditation for its unique liberal arts and Islamic studies programs
baseline_narrative.summary: Located in Berkeley, California, Zaytuna College offers specialized degree programs including a Bachelor of Arts in Liberal Arts and Islamic Studies and a Master of Arts in Islamic Texts [3][4]. The institution operates as a zakat-eligible entity, focusing on preparing morally committed leaders through a rigorous curriculum that integrates classical Islamic disciplines with contemporary humanities [1][8].

case_against.summary: The primary concern is financial efficiency; the college <cite id="41">spends roughly 40% of its budget</cite> on non-programmatic costs.

confidence.notes: Financial data is highly reliable; impact data is based on accreditation status.

known_gaps: Missing specific graduate career placement rates

alignment.explanation: Strong alignment for donors seeking <cite id="38">Islamic institutional development</cite> with <cite id="39">verified zakat eligibility</cite> for student aid.
alignment.improvement: Clarifying the <cite id="40">zakat allocation policy</cite> and specific eligible categories would improve donor fit.

credibility.explanation: Zaytuna is highly credible due to its <cite id="30">WASC accreditation</cite> and <cite id="31">Gold Seal of Transparency</cite>. It maintains an <cite id="32">independent board of 12 members</cite> and undergoes <cite id="33">regular financial audits</cite>.
credibility.improvement: To strengthen credibility further, the college could <cite id="34">publish consistent beneficiary counts</cite> and career outcome data for its graduates.

impact.explanation: Impact is driven by <cite id="35">capacity building</cite> through higher education, though the <cite id="36">56.0% program ratio</cite> suggests high administrative costs relative to peers.
impact.improvement: The college should <cite id="37">publish a time-bound plan</cite> to deploy excess unrestricted reserves into mission delivery.

grantmaking_profile.grant_strategy: Direct educational service provider, not a grantmaking foundation

rich_narrative.headline: Zaytuna College serves as the first accredited Muslim liberal arts college in the United States, dedicated to grounding students in both Islamic and Western scholarly traditions.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who value long-term Islamic institutional development and want to invest in the intellectual infrastructure of the American Muslim community.
donor_motivations: Want to support the first accredited Muslim college in the West
Value the integration of classical Islamic knowledge with liberal arts
Prefer supporting students through zakat-eligible scholarships
Prioritize institutional stability and long-term sustainability
giving_considerations: Donations support a high-overhead academic environment necessary for accreditation
The college holds significant reserves, meaning gifts contribute to long-term growth rather than immediate emergency relief
Impact is measured in decades through the leadership of graduates
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking high-efficiency emergency relief or those who prioritize organizations with very low administrative overhead.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade B reflects formal academic accreditation and documented curriculum, though specific long-term career outcome data is not fully public.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: Zaytuna creates impact by educating morally committed leaders who can navigate both Islamic and Western intellectual landscapes, thereby strengthening the community's leadership capacity.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Accreditation ensures that the educational 'product' meets national standards for quality and rigor.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: While the college has high reserves, its strategic expansion into graduate programs and campus development requires ongoing capital.

peer_comparison.differentiator: Distinguished by being the <cite id="44">only accredited Muslim liberal arts college</cite> in the US.

strengths.detail: The college spends only <cite id="15">$0.11 to raise every $1</cite>, indicating highly efficient development operations.
Zaytuna maintains <cite id="16">33.6 months of working capital</cite>, providing a massive safety net for long-term institutional sustainability.
The institution is <cite id="17">WASC Accredited</cite>, ensuring its degrees meet rigorous <cite id="18">Senior College and University Commission</cite> standards.

strengths_deep_dive: Zaytuna College's primary strength lies in its institutional maturity and financial resilience. With <cite id="19">net assets exceeding $42 million</cite> and a <cite id="20">revenue growth rate of 19.7%</cite>, the college has successfully transitioned from a startup to an established institution. Its <cite id="21">Gold Seal of Transparency from Candid</cite> reflects a commitment to public disclosure. Furthermore, the college's ability to generate <cite id="22">$2.36 million in program service revenue</cite> alongside donations demonstrates a diversifying financial base that supports its <cite id="23">accredited academic mission</cite>.
rich_narrative.summary: Founded in <cite id="1">2009</cite> in Berkeley, California, Zaytuna College represents a historic milestone as the <cite id="2">first accredited Muslim liberal arts college</cite> in the United States. The institution is dedicated to grounding students in both the <cite id="3">Islamic and Western scholarly traditions</cite>, offering specialized degree programs such as a <cite id="4">Bachelor of Arts in Liberal Arts and Islamic Studies</cite> and a <cite id="5">Master of Arts in Islamic Texts</cite>. Financially, the college demonstrated significant growth with a <cite id="6">3-year revenue CAGR of 19.7%</cite>, reaching <cite id="7">$18,359,667 in total revenue</cite> for the 2023 tax year. While the college maintains <cite id="8">high financial stability</cite> with <cite id="9">33.6 months of working capital</cite>, its <cite id="10">program expense ratio of 56.0%</cite> remains below the median for its peer group. The college operates as a <cite id="11">zakat-eligible entity</cite>, allowing donors to support students through <cite id="12">zakat-eligible scholarships</cite> for those in need. Beyond its core degree programs, Zaytuna extends its impact through community initiatives like the <cite id="13">12000 Strong</cite> program and various <cite id="14">online courses</cite> designed to broaden access to classical Islamic knowledge.
